awd_titl_txt: Nationally Representative Survey on Financialization, Work Organization, and Job Training
awd_abstract_narration:
The U.S. labor market has recently seen both increased income inequality and proliferation of low-wage jobs. Some contend that a driving force behind these developments is increased financialization of the economy. This argument holds that pressures stemming from shareholders, financial institutions, and financialized management strategies have altered the way firms and managers structure jobs, potentially diminishing firm investments in human capital and eroding job quality in favor of increased profits. Thus, short-term financial considerations have displaced more far-sighted management approaches that are beneficial to both workers and firms. Despite the frequency of these assertions, supporting data are scarce. This project evaluates these arguments by conducting a nationally representative survey of business establishments across three industries. The data will be used to test whether variation in job structure and quality are related to variation in measures of financialization. The project speaks to societal  concerns regarding economic inequality and changes in the distribution of high- and low-wage jobs in the U.S. economy. This information will be of interest to policymakers concerned with job and economic growth both nationally and at the state and local levels.
 

           This project will construct a nationally representative survey of establishments in three industries that are part of matched firms that have been subjected to greater and lesser levels of financialization, with a targeted sample size of 1,200-1,600 establishments. These industries include: 1) professional, scientific, and technical services; 2) computer and electronic manufacturing; and 3) retail. This choice of industries allows for focused attention on how financialization pressures affect science and technology workers and how these pressures differ from those found in other industries. The survey will ask detailed questions about job quality and structure, including questions about wages, contingent labor, skill demands, job tenure, training, and promotion policies. The target respondents are human resource managers who are employed at the randomly-selected business establishments. The establishment survey will be linked with lagged firm-level indicators of financialization, corporate governance, and shareholder ownership drawn from several business databases used in prior research.  The uniqueness of the survey data will allow analyses of relationships between firm-level indicators and establishment-level work outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The rise in income inequality and job insecurity for low- and middle-income workers in America has sparked numerous theories about changes in work structure and employment relationships. One prominent theory is “financialization,” which suggests that financial actors and perspectives increasingly influence corporate strategies and economic outcomes. This project investigates how financialization affects job quality, work organization, and job training.

Key findings from previous research indicate that financial sector growth has redistributed income towards the financial sector, reduced labor’s share of income, and led to employment declines. This project tests these claims by gathering detailed data on job quality and work organization at the establishment level.

The project seeks to clarify the impact of financialization on job quality by conducting a nationally representative survey of business establishments. The survey focuses on three key industries: professional, scientific, and technical services; computer and electronic manufacturing; and retail. These industries were chosen for their variation in financialization measures and their significant employment numbers.

The research design included three main aims:

  1. Conduct a Representative Survey: The survey gathered detailed establishment-level data on job quality and work organization, including wages, training, job tenure, and promotion policies.
  2. Link Survey Data with Financial Measures: The survey data were linked with firm-level measures of financialization, such as ownership concentration, shareholder activism, and financial transactions.
  3. Analyze Relationships: The project analyzes the relationship between financial characteristics and job quality, controlling for various firm, industry, and geographic factors. Although data collection is complete, quantitative analyses are ongoing at the time of writing.

The project has several broader impacts for public policy and academic inquiry:

  1. Policy Implications: By providing new data on how financialization pressures affect job quality, the study informs policy debates on improving conditions for low- and moderate-income workers. Understanding these detailed processes is essential for crafting appropriate public policies.
  2. Academic Contributions: The study contributes to academic debates on work, organizations, and the evolution of the employment relationship. It provides new insights into how financialization pressures shape job training policies, hiring practices, and other human capital policies at the establishment level.
  3. Data Availability: The survey data will be made publicly available, allowing other researchers to explore the relationship between financialization and job quality further.

This project provides valuable insights into the impact of financialization on job quality and work organization. By linking detailed establishment-level data with firm-level financial measures, the study offers a nuanced understanding of how financial pressures shape employment practices. These findings are crucial for informing public policy and advancing academic research on the future of work.
